titleStmt.title: Despatch from Albert Bushnell to Frederick W. Seward, February 1, 1878

bibl.title: Despatch from Albert Bushnell to Frederick W. Seward
Despatches from United States Consuls in Gaboon, 1856-1888 T-466

div1.p:
United States Commercial Agency at Gaboon,
February 1st 1878.

Hon F W Seward,
Assistant Secretary of State,
Washington, D.C.

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your Dispatch No 11th, leaving date, October 24th 1877, on the 18th of January 1878, almost three months from the time it was written. Our mails during the past year, have been irregular, with an interval of from six to eight weeks, between them. The last steamer was just two months, from Liverpool, to Gaboon. The steamers, now having no government subsidy, call at numerous ports on the Coast, & often are delayed for freight. There is a merchant steamer, which will take these dispatches, that make much quicker passages, but it brings no mails. This irregularity & detention of our mails is my apology for asking for leave of absense, so long in advance. I doubt not the leave of absense has been granted; &is in route for Gaboon; & I hope it will be received by next steamer from Liverpool; which is due here on to the 21 inst. for the following steamer will not arrive till about the 10th of April,
and not return till May. Although I have nominated Rev. S. H. Murphy as vice Commercial Agent, & doubt not his appointment has been made; I do not like to leave my post; till I have received my leave of absence; & shall not, unless the state of my health imperitively demands it. My medical advisor, The French Surgeon in Chief of the Colony, assured me this morning that my departure ought not be long postponed.

I beg to remain
Sir;
Respectfully,
Your Obedient Servant,
Albert Bushnell
United S. Com. Agent
